div.sent: The religion of the Buddha is the religion of welfare for all mankind.
In this religion the Buddha not only preached the religious thoughts but also kept many messages and advices for the welfare of men.
Later those messages became the part and parcel of the social rules.
Man is a social animal.
So everyone should live unitedly in the society.
Because unity is the strength.
In this respect Gautama Buddha mentioned about seven unavoidable duties for all.
The word Aparihaniya in Pali means indispensable or obligatory.
So Satta Aparihaniya Dhamma means seven obligatory rules of the religion.
To keep them united, the Buddha admonished the Vajjis of Vaisali the seven indispensable rules and impressed them to obey the rules.
It is known as Satta Aparihaniya Dhamma in Buddhism.
The Vajjis of Vaisali are also known as the Briji.
During the life of Gautama Buddha, Vaisaii was a very rich city.
Once the city was in the grip of sudden famine, epidemic diseases and oppression of wicked persons.
They began to think how they could save the city from those three kinds of tyranny.
Then they remembered Gautama Buddha.
They thought, Buddha was compassionate one.
He surely would rescue them from the danger.
Then they went to the Buddha.
Gautama Buddha went to Vaisali on their request.
As soon as he had reached in the city it began to rain cats and dogs.
As a result, the rotten rubbish were washed away by the flow of water.
Then by the order of the Buddha, Ananda recited the Ratana Sutta moving all around in the city.
After the recitation of the sutta was over the city became free from oppression.
The people of the city became happy at this.
So they built Shrines there.
Gautama Buddha stayed at the temples for many days.
While staying there in Sarandada Chaitya he advised the Vajji to live in unitedly and preached seven indispensable duties.
From the time that they were united, there did not happen any oppression and happened no anomalous or any anarchy in the country.
The enemy from the outside did not dare to attack their country.
Even the king Ajatasattu, did not attack them.
Then the son of Bimbisara, prince Ajatasattu was the king of Magadha.
Vaisali was the neighbour-country.
Vaisali was the rich city of the Vajji.
The Ganges was flown in the border of both of the kingdoms.
There was a big port on the bank of the Ganges.
Half of the port was under the possession of the Vajji and the other half with Magadha.
That means both of them had an authority over the port.
At times the most valuable things used to come there in the port.
The Vajjis were united.
The Vajji would buy those valuable things before king Ajatasattu appeared there.
Ajatasattu often went back in despair.
But he became angry as he had to go back in vain again and again.
Then he determined to attack Vaisali.
Before attacking he thought that the Vajjis were strong.
They were educated and united.
As they were united so their mental force was very strong.
There was no certainty to defeat them.
So he thought to discuss with Samyaka Sambuddha before attacking them.
So thinking he sent a minister named Varsakar to the Buddha.
Buddha was then living at Griddhrakut in Rajagriha.
Showing respect to the Buddha, Varsakar informed Him about the intention of Ajatasattu.
Ananda was then present there.
In reply the Buddha cited about the obeying of the seven rules by the Vajji.
He informed that those are the origin of their riches and the source of their un- destroyable strength.
As long as the Vajji gathered in the meetings and the conferences they would prosper and there would have no cause for downfall.
As many days the Vajji would be united, worked together unanimously, they would be enriched but not be downfall.
Then the Buddha said to the Brahmin, 0 Brahmin, once I advised the Vajjis to obey the Satta Aparihaniya Dhamma.
As many days they would perform them, their country would prosper and none could defeat them.
The Seven Aparihaniya Dhamma that have been explained till now we all should perform them.
We should go unitedly in the conference that held in the villages and wards.
Then we should return our home in a body after the meeting is over.
If any decision is taken in the meeting they should be obeyed at a time.
Nobody should take the shelter of injustice.
This will cause loss to the society and the country and retard progress.
Beyond this, everyone should respect to the superiors and the woman should be honoured.
The temples should be re-built.
Gifted wealth of the religion should not be enjoyed by the individuals.
The virtuous should be honoured.
These are the best works.
It may bring good to the people.
The country will be enriched.
The Vajjis obeyed these, so nothing stood in their way to prosperity.
Later, the Seven Aparihaniya Doctrines were also introduced for the monks from the seven doctrines of the Vajjis.
Thus the Satta Aparihaniya Dhamma is our protector.
We should obey each of the precepts that contain in it.
